G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 6 and G.L. c. 208, § 28, which empower the Probate and Family Court to modify judgments relating to child custody and visitation upon a material and substantial change in circumstances.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, the Probate and Family Court may modify a custody or visitation order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, the Probate and Family Court may modify a custody or visitation order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the best interests of the child.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The controlling standard is the best interests of the child.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly interprets the Massachusetts removal statute to require that removal be in the best interests of the child and characterizes those best interests as the central and paramount concern in the analysis. Although the court also discusses the custodial parent’s “real advantage,” it makes clear that this is a component of, and subordinate to, the best‑interests standard, not a separate controlling test.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … [a child] shall not … be removed out of this commonwealth … unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child … and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The controlling standard is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the governing standard in custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a) and reaffirms that the ‘best interests of the child’ standard is the controlling inquiry. The court both traces the historical Massachusetts rule that custody decisions turn on the child’s best interests and holds that § 10(a)’s specific factors do not replace that standard but guide its application. Thus, the case is proper authority for the proposition that the controlling standard is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Court must assess whether a change of circumstances has occurred that affects the child’s welfare significantly enough to require modification.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case concerns a removal request under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint physical custody setting and focuses directly on applying a best interests standard to the proposed relocation. It does not frame the issue as a threshold requirement to find a "change of circumstances" significantly affecting the child’s welfare in order to modify an existing custody or parenting plan; instead, it treats the relocation itself as the subject of a best‑interests analysis under the removal statute. The ALI Principles quoted mention relocation as a substantial change in circumstances, but the court does not adopt that as a Massachusetts rule about modification standards.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:
“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce] …
“(4) When a relocation constituting changed circumstances . . . renders it impractical to maintain the same proportion of custodial responsibility to each parent, the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests …”

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: The Court must assess whether a change of circumstances has occurred that affects the child’s welfare significantly enough to require modification.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: The opinion clearly states that to modify child support or alimony, the petitioner must show a material change in circumstances since the earlier judgment, and that the judge must weigh all relevant circumstances, including the needs of the children and the parents’ financial status. While the case frames the statutory standard as “as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require,” it functionally requires an assessment whether changed circumstances significantly affect the welfare/benefit of the children so as to justify modification. The language is close enough in substance to support the proposition, though the exact phrasing “significantly enough to require modification” is not used verbatim.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ … The needs of the children, the financial status of the support provider, and the station in life of the respective parties must all be considered.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Massachusetts recognizes that evidence of substance abuse or impaired parenting may constitute such a change.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is about domestic violence and its impact on custody determinations, not about substance abuse or impaired parenting as a distinct change in circumstances. While the facts briefly mention the parties’ past alcohol and marijuana use and the father’s sobriety, the court does not frame substance abuse or impaired parenting as a “change” justifying modification, nor articulate any rule that such evidence constitutes a change in circumstances. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "Finally, the Probate Court judge noted that the father, who had been a heavy drinker, had not used alcohol since 1985 and attends weekly sessions of Alcoholics Anonymous. The court also mandated that both parents should remain in therapy."

Care and Protection of Isaac, 419 Mass..raw_text: Care and Protection of Isaac, 419 Mass. 602 (1995)
Care and Protection of Isaac, 419 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts recognizes that evidence of substance abuse or impaired parenting may constitute such a change.
Care and Protection of Isaac, 419 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion in Care and Protection of Isaac concerns the scope of judicial authority to order specific residential placements and staffing levels for a child in the custody of the Department of Social Services. It does not discuss or analyze substance abuse, impaired parenting, or what constitutes a sufficient "change" in circumstances. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that Massachusetts recognizes evidence of substance abuse or impaired parenting as such a change.
Care and Protection of Isaac, 419 Mass..relevant_excerpt: Paragraph 4 of § 26 is, primarily, the means by which a parent or other interested party, including the department, may bring to a judge’s attention a change in the situation of a child, or of a child’s parent, which might warrant reconsideration or modification of the original order adjudicating the child in need of care and protection. See Custody of a Minor (No. 3), 378 Mass. 732, 734 (1979).

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).proposition: A parent’s responsibility includes protecting the child from exposure to unsafe environments and impaired caretaking.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the State’s authority to intervene when parents are unable to provide a child with necessary care and protection, but its focus is on standards for state removal of custody and the parental-unfitness test, not on defining the substantive scope of a parent’s responsibilities. While it mentions ‘care and protection’ and ‘endangerment,’ it does not frame or articulate a specific affirmative duty of parents to shield children from unsafe environments or impaired caretaking, and in fact criticizes reliance on lifestyle judgments rather than concrete endangerment. Thus the case does not clearly establish the proposition as a legal principle.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755 (1983).relevant_excerpt: “State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection. … It is not the quality or character of parental conduct per se that justifies State intervention on behalf of an abused, neglected, or otherwise endangered child. Rather, it is the fact of the endangerment itself. As parens patriae the State does not act to punish misbehaving parents; rather it acts to protect endangered children.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: A parent’s responsibility includes protecting the child from exposure to unsafe environments and impaired caretaking.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on best‑interests analysis in choosing between two adoptive placements after both parents have already been found unfit. While it discusses the need for a stable, supportive, and developmentally appropriate home environment, it does not articulate a general legal principle that a biological parent’s responsibility includes protecting a child from unsafe environments and impaired caretaking. The parents’ responsibilities are not framed in those terms; instead, their unfitness is simply noted as an undisputed background fact.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: The judge made extensive findings regarding each parent’s unfitness to parent Hugo. Among other things, he found that the mother had a continuing pattern of neglecting her children, had failed to receive treatment for her mental health problems that included a diagnosis of chronic paranoid schizophrenia, had failed to deal with her substance abuse, and had not dealt with issues of domestic violence with the father. The judge also found that, among other things, the father’s pattern of substance abuse, domestic violence, and neglect of his older child rendered him unfit to parent Hugo.

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: The Court retains continuing jurisdiction to revise or revoke custody orders when the welfare of the minor child so requires.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns modification of child support, attachment to secure support and college expenses, and modification of legal custody. It does not discuss the court’s continuing jurisdiction in general terms or articulate a principle that custody orders may be revised or revoked whenever the child’s welfare so requires. While it applies G.L. c. 208, § 28 to a custody modification, it does not frame this as an ongoing jurisdictional rule as stated in the proposition.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: The Court retains continuing jurisdiction to revise or revoke custody orders when the welfare of the minor child so requires.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The court expressly recognizes that custody orders for minor children are subject to future modification and cites both the governing statute and prior case law on this point. By referencing G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30 and Hersey v. Hersey regarding circumstances in which custody orders may be modified, the opinion affirms that the Probate Court retains continuing jurisdiction to revise or revoke custody orders as the child’s welfare requires.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “We hold that the judge correctly applied these principles in deciding this case and that on the facts found and reported by him he did not abuse his discretion. As to the circumstances in which orders for the custody of minor children may be subject to future modification by the court see G. L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30, Palmer v. Palmer, 357 Mass. 764 (1970), and Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 550 (1930).”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Allegations of parental impairment have consistently been found sufficient to reopen custody determinations where corroborated by observations, third‑party reports, or school impacts.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion is an appeal from an original divorce and custody judgment, not a petition to reopen or modify an existing custody determination based on new allegations of parental impairment. While the court discusses parental fitness, best interests, and some negative conduct (e.g., hygiene during visitation), it does not address the legal standard for reopening custody judgments or hold that corroborated allegations of impairment are sufficient to reopen such orders. Therefore it provides no authority for the specific proposition about reopening custody determinations.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: "Nor did he present any evidence showing that the wife’s perception caused ‘“deleterious effect[s]’ on the children and an ‘undermining’ of the custodial relationship,’ Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 240 (1981), or that sole custody in him would be in the children’s best interests.... From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order."
